public_information: There are three pegs named left, middle, and right.
There are 8 disks labeled A,B,C,D,E,F,G,H from smallest (A) to largest (H).
Only one disk may be moved at a time.
A larger disk may never be placed on top of a smaller disk.
Initial configuration: left peg has top-to-bottom A,B,C,D,E,F,G,H; middle peg is empty; right peg is empty.
Goal configuration: right peg has top-to-bottom A,B,C,D,E,F,G,H; left and middle pegs are empty.

report.system_prompt: You are the agent responsible for the left peg. You know the local stack of disks on your peg and must produce a concise structured state report describing the stack top-to-bottom and any relevant relations such as which disk is on which or which disks are on the table. Do not produce PDDL. Provide only the facts necessary to reconstruct the local state.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert in multi-agent planning and PDDL authoring. Your job is to integrate the structured state reports from the peg agents and produce a complete PDDL domain and problem suitable for the FastDownwards planner. The domain must model pegs, disks, legal moves, the one-disk-at-a-time constraint, and the rule forbidding placing a larger disk on a smaller disk. The problem must encode the initial state and the goal state where all disks are stacked on the right peg in correct order. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. Keep agent actions distinct conceptually if modeling multi-agent moves, but the resulting PDDL must be directly solvable by FastDownwards.
pddl.prompt: You are the orchestrator. You receive structured state reports from the peg agents as inputs. Integrate these reports to construct a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem for the Tower of Hanoi instance with 8 disks and pegs left, middle, and right. Target the FastDownwards solver and ensure the PDDL is complete and consistent. Enclose the domain between <domain></domain> and the problem between <problem></problem>.
